intro: Tetrapterys acutifolia, commonly known as the sharp-leaved sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its distinctive, palmately lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in summer, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. Tetrapterys acutifolia thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
